docs.title: Linux Distributions
docs.text: This section contains notes on the different Linux distributions I use regularly.

docs.title: Arch-based Distributions
docs.text:
Arch Linux is known for its simplicity, modernity, pragmatism, user centrality, and versatility. Arch-based distributions build upon this foundation while adding their own features and tools.

  • EndeavourOS: A rolling release distro based on Arch Linux that aims to be lightweight and easy to use while staying close to pure Arch.

docs.title: Debian-based Distributions
docs.text:
Debian is known for its stability, extensive software repositories, and commitment to free software principles. Many popular distributions are based on Debian.

  • Ubuntu: One of the most popular Linux distributions, known for its ease of use and regular release schedule.
  • Xubuntu: Ubuntu with the lightweight XFCE desktop environment.
  • Pop!_OS: System76's Ubuntu-based distribution focused on creators and makers.

docs.text:
These topics apply across different distributions:

  • Package Management Comparison: How package management works across different distributions.
  • Desktop Environments: Overview of different desktop environments available on Linux.
  • Terminal Essentials: Terminal tools and configurations that work across distributions.

docs.title: EndeavourOS
docs.text: EndeavourOS is an Arch-based Linux distribution that aims to be lightweight and easy to use while staying close to pure Arch Linux.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
EndeavourOS is the spiritual successor to Antergos, providing a user-friendly installation process for an Arch-based system. It offers:

  • A graphical installer (Calamares)
  • A selection of desktop environments
  • A helpful and friendly community
  • Rolling release model (like Arch)
  • Access to the Arch User Repository (AUR)

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Welcome App: Provides system information and quick access to common tasks
  • Hardware Detection: Good out-of-the-box hardware support
  • Package Management: Uses pacman (Arch's package manager) and supports AUR helpers like yay
  • Desktop Choice: Offers multiple desktop environments during installation

docs.title: EndeavourOS Updates
docs.text: This page covers how to update your EndeavourOS system and best practices for system maintenance.

docs.title: Basic System Update
docs.text:
EndeavourOS, being Arch-based, uses pacman as its package manager. To update your system:

# Update package databases and upgrade all packages
sudo pacman -Syu

docs.title: Using AUR Helpers
docs.text:
For packages from the Arch User Repository (AUR), you can use helpers like yay:

# Update system packages and AUR packages
yay -Syu

# Update only AUR packages
yay -Sua

docs.title: Update Frequency
docs.text:
Since EndeavourOS is a rolling release distribution, it's recommended to:

  • Update at least once a week
  • Check the EndeavourOS news before major updates
  • Consider joining the EndeavourOS forum to stay informed about critical updates

docs.title: Handling Partial Updates
docs.text: Partial updates are not recommended in Arch-based systems. Always use -Syu to ensure all packages are updated together.

docs.title: Dealing with Package Conflicts
docs.text:
If you encounter package conflicts during updates:

  1. Read the conflict message carefully
  2. Check the Arch news for any known issues
  3. Search the EndeavourOS forum for solutions
  4. In most cases, accepting the default resolution is safe

docs.title: After Updates
docs.text:
After major updates, consider:

  1. Checking if any .pacnew configuration files were created: 

    find /etc -name "*.pacnew"

  2. Rebooting if the kernel or graphics drivers were updated

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If your system won't boot after an update:

  1. Boot from the EndeavourOS live USB
  2. Mount your system and chroot into it: 
    sudo mount /dev/sdaX /mnt  # Replace sdaX with your root partition
sudo arch-chroot /mnt
  3. Downgrade problematic packages or reinstall the kernel

docs.text: This page compares package management systems across different Linux distributions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Distribution Package Manager Package Format Command Examples Arch/EndeavourOS pacman .pkg.tar.xz pacman -S, pacman -Syu Ubuntu/Xubuntu/Pop!_OS apt .deb apt install, apt update Fedora dnf .rpm dnf install, dnf update openSUSE zypper .rpm zypper install, zypper update

docs.title: Key Commands
docs.text:
# Update package database and upgrade all packages
sudo pacman -Syu

# Install a package
sudo pacman -S package_name

# Remove a package
sudo pacman -R package_name

# Remove a package and its dependencies
sudo pacman -Rs package_name

# Search for a package
pacman -Ss search_term

# List installed packages
pacman -Q

# Get information about a package
pacman -Qi package_name

docs.title: AUR Helpers
docs.text:
For the Arch User Repository (AUR), common helpers include:

# Using yay
yay -S package_name
yay -Syu  # Update system and AUR packages

# Using paru
paru -S package_name
paru -Syu  # Update system and AUR packages

docs.title: Key Commands
docs.text:
# Update package database
sudo apt update

# Upgrade installed packages
sudo apt upgrade

# Install a package
sudo apt install package_name

# Remove a package
sudo apt remove package_name

# Remove a package and its configuration files
sudo apt purge package_name

# Search for a package
apt search search_term

# List installed packages
apt list --installed

# Get information about a package
apt show package_name

docs.title: Additional Package Sources
docs.text:
# Add a PPA repository
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:user/repository

# Install from a .deb file
sudo dpkg -i package.deb
sudo apt install -f  # Fix dependencies if needed

docs.title: Common Tasks Across Distributions
docs.text: Task Arch/EndeavourOS Ubuntu/Debian Update system sudo pacman -Syu sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade Install package sudo pacman -S pkg sudo apt install pkg Remove package sudo pacman -R pkg sudo apt remove pkg Search packages pacman -Ss term apt search term Clean cache sudo pacman -Sc sudo apt clean Fix broken packages sudo pacman -Syyu sudo apt --fix-broken install

docs.title: Package Management Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Regular Updates: Keep your system updated regularly for security and stability
  2. Read Before Upgrading: Check release notes before major upgrades
  3. Backup First: Always backup important data before major system upgrades
  4. Use Official Repositories: Prefer official repositories when possible
  5. Clean Package Cache: Periodically clean package caches to free disk space

docs.title: Ubuntu
docs.text: Ubuntu is one of the most popular Linux distributions, based on Debian and maintained by Canonical.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Ubuntu follows a regular release schedule with: - Standard releases every 6 months (supported for 9 months) - LTS (Long Term Support) releases every 2 years (supported for 5 years)

The current LTS release is Ubuntu 22.04 (Jammy Jellyfish), supported until April 2027.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• User-Friendly: Designed to be accessible for beginners
  • Software Center: Graphical interface for installing applications
  • Snap Support: Built-in support for Snap packages
  • Desktop Environment: Uses GNOME as the default desktop environment
  • Large Community: Extensive documentation and community support

docs.title: Ubuntu Updates
docs.text: This page covers how to update your Ubuntu system and best practices for system maintenance.

docs.title: Graphical Update Method
docs.text:
The simplest way to update Ubuntu is through the Software Updater:

  1. Open the "Software Updater" application
  2. Click "Check for updates"
  3. If updates are available, click "Install Now"
  4. Enter your password when prompted

docs.title: Command Line Update Method
docs.text:
To update Ubuntu via the terminal:

# Update package lists
sudo apt update

# Upgrade installed packages
sudo apt upgrade

# Optional: Upgrade distribution packages (may include new package versions)
sudo apt dist-upgrade

# Remove unnecessary packages
sudo apt autoremove

docs.title: Release Upgrades
docs.text:
To upgrade to a new Ubuntu release:

# For graphical environments
sudo update-manager -c

# For server/terminal environments
sudo do-release-upgrade

docs.title: Update Frequency
docs.text:
• Security Updates: Install as soon as possible
  • Regular Updates: At least once a month is recommended
  • Release Upgrades: Plan carefully, backup data first

docs.title: Automatic Updates
docs.text:
To configure automatic security updates:

# Install the unattended-upgrades package
sudo apt install unattended-upgrades

# Configure automatic updates
sudo dpkg-reconfigure unattended-upgrades

docs.title: Checking Update Status
docs.text:
To see which packages need updating:

apt list --upgradable

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: If you encounter issues with updates:

docs.title: Fixing Package Database Issues
docs.text:
sudo apt clean
sudo apt update --fix-missing

docs.title: Resolving Broken Dependencies
docs.text: sudo apt --fix-broken install

docs.title: Handling Locked Database Errors
docs.text:
If you see "Could not get lock" errors:

# Check what's using the package database
ps aux | grep -i apt

# If nothing is found, remove the lock files
sudo rm /var/lib/apt/lists/lock
sudo rm /var/cache/apt/archives/lock
sudo rm /var/lib/dpkg/lock*
sudo dpkg --configure -a

docs.title: Bash Cheatsheet
docs.text: This page provides a quick reference for Bash shell commands and scripting.

docs.title: Basic Commands
docs.text:
# Display text
echo "Hello World"

# Set a variable
name="Linux"
echo "Hello $name"

# Command substitution
current_dir=$(pwd)
echo "Current directory: $current_dir"

# Arithmetic operations
result=$((5 + 3))
echo "5 + 3 = $result"

docs.title: If-Else Statement
docs.text:
if [ "$name" = "Linux" ]; then
    echo "Name is Linux"
elif [ "$name" = "BSD" ]; then
    echo "Name is BSD"
else
    echo "Name is something else"
fi

docs.title: Loops
docs.text:
# For loop
for i in 1 2 3 4 5; do
    echo "Number: $i"
done

# While loop
count=1
while [ $count -le 5 ]; do
    echo "Count: $count"
    count=$((count + 1))
done

# Until loop
count=1
until [ $count -gt 5 ]; do
    echo "Count: $count"
    count=$((count + 1))
done

docs.title: Case Statement
docs.text:
case "$name" in
    "Linux")
        echo "It's Linux"
        ;;
    "BSD")
        echo "It's BSD"
        ;;
    *)
        echo "Unknown operating system"
        ;;
esac

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
# Define a function
greet() {
    echo "Hello, $1!"
}

# Call the function
greet "World"

docs.title: String Operations
docs.text:
string="Hello World"

# String length
echo ${#string}

# Substring
echo ${string:0:5}  # "Hello"

# Replace
echo ${string/World/Linux}  # "Hello Linux"

docs.title: File Operations
docs.text:
# Check if file exists
if [ -f "/path/to/file" ]; then
    echo "File exists"
fi

# Check if directory exists
if [ -d "/path/to/directory" ]; then
    echo "Directory exists"
fi

# Read file line by line
while IFS= read -r line; do
    echo "$line"
done < "/path/to/file"

docs.title: Essential Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example ls List directory contents ls -la cd Change directory cd /etc pwd Print working directory pwd cp Copy files or directories cp file.txt backup/ mv Move/rename files or directories mv old.txt new.txt rm Remove files or directories rm -rf directory/ mkdir Create directories mkdir -p new/sub/dir grep Search text using patterns grep "error" log.txt find Search for files find / -name "*.conf" chmod Change file permissions chmod +x script.sh chown Change file owner chown user:group file.txt ps Show process status ps aux kill Terminate processes kill -9 1234 df Show disk space usage df -h du Show directory space usage du -sh * top Display running processes top man Show manual pages man ls

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
Most Linux commands follow this basic structure:

command [options] arguments
  • Command: The program name (e.g., ls, cp)
  • Options: Modify the command's behavior (e.g., -l, --all)
  • Arguments: What the command acts upon (e.g., filenames, directories)

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
There are several ways to get help with commands:

# View the manual page

# Get brief help
command_name --help

# Get information about a command

# Show a brief description
whatis command_name

docs.title: Command History

# Run previous command

# Simple backup script

echo "Backup completed: $BACKUP_DIR/backup-$DATE.tar.gz"

docs.title: System Updates Across Distributions
docs.text: This page provides a unified approach to system updates across different Linux distributions.

docs.title: Arch-based (EndeavourOS)
docs.text:
# Update package database and upgrade all packages
sudo pacman -Syu

# Update AUR packages (if using yay)
yay -Syu

docs.title: Debian-based (Ubuntu, Xubuntu, Pop!_OS)
docs.text:
# Update package database
sudo apt update

# Upgrade installed packages
sudo apt upgrade

# Optional: Upgrade with potential new dependencies
sudo apt dist-upgrade

# Clean up unused packages
sudo apt autoremove

docs.title: Update Frequency Recommendations
docs.text: Distribution Type Recommended Frequency Notes Rolling Release (Arch/EndeavourOS) Weekly Check news before major updates Standard Release (Ubuntu/etc.) Monthly Enable automatic security updates LTS Releases Monthly Focus on stability

docs.title: Best Practices for All Distributions
docs.text:
1. Backup Before Major Updates: Always backup important data before significant system updates
  2. Read Release Notes: Check distribution news or forums before major updates
  3. Update During Low-Usage Times: Schedule updates when you don't need immediate access to your system
  4. Reboot When Needed: Reboot after kernel updates or major system library updates
  5. Verify Success: Check that your system works properly after updates

docs.title: Arch-based Systems
docs.text:
Create a simple systemd timer:

# Create the service file
sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/pacman-update.service

# Add the following content
[Unit]
Description=Pacman update

[Service]
Type=oneshot
ExecStart=/usr/bin/pacman -Syu --noconfirm

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

Create the timer:

# Create the timer file
sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/pacman-update.timer

# Add the following content
[Unit]
Description=Run pacman update weekly

[Timer]
OnCalendar=weekly
Persistent=true

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target

Enable the timer:

sudo systemctl enable pacman-update.timer
sudo systemctl start pacman-update.timer

docs.title: Debian-based Systems
docs.text:
Install and configure unattended-upgrades:

# Install the package
sudo apt install unattended-upgrades apt-listchanges

# Configure
sudo dpkg-reconfigure unattended-upgrades

Edit the configuration:

sudo nano /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/50unattended-upgrades

docs.title: Common Issues and Solutions
docs.text: Issue Solution Locked package database Wait for other package operations to complete or remove lock files Broken dependencies Use sudo apt --fix-broken install (Debian) or pacman -Syyu (Arch) Failed downloads Check internet connection and try again Disk space issues Clear package cache and remove unused packages Conflicting packages Read error messages carefully and research the specific conflict

docs.title: Recovery Options
docs.text:
If an update breaks your system:

  1. Boot from a live USB
  2. Mount your system partition
  3. Chroot into the system
  4. Downgrade problematic packages or perform repairs
